messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] back on track with a tsuba question
messages.msgSnippet: Hirado Kunishige and others made nanban-style fittings in brass decorated with nonsense inscriptions in roman characters.  Some of the letters are correct, but
messages.messageBody:
Hirado Kunishige and others made nanban-style fittings in brass decorated with nonsense inscriptions in roman characters. Some of the letters are correct, but others are upside down, backwards or simply made up. Some resemble Greek letters.

This isn't Kunishige's work and the characters, whatever they are, are more "freestyle" than is usually seen in that type of nanban work. A couple of the characters do resemble tensho script. It's not one of the common nanban styles, but dote mimi examples do exist and the iron has the grainy quality seen in a lot of nanban tsuba.

Late Hoan would usually be etched rather than carved. The iron, finishing and carving don't look like Myochin, although they did make small, bold guards. As always, seeing it in person could give a different impression.

Jim



All, yes, that was a responce I was puzzled by, thus I threw it out
there, here is another I have had and like

I believe they represent the most ancient form of Chinese characters. Oracle bone inscriptions from the
Shang -Zhou dynasty (2000-1000 BC)Stone drum inscriptions from the Warring states period (3rd cent. BC).
I have seen similar tsuba papered as later Hoan by the Fittings Museum.

I believe this tsuba may be a copy of something, there is a rather 'ODD' feel to it, it is pretty light for it's size as well.

RIch

Ron Hartmann wrote:

> Rich -
>
> Namban tsuba. Must agree with other commenst that this does not look

> well-rounded edge, I wonder if this might be Satsuma work. Just a
> gut-feeling guess.
>
> Ron
> STL
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: Richard Turner
> To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
> Sent: Wednesday, January 05, 2005 8:53 PM
> Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] back on track with a tsuba question
>
>
> Thanks Jim, interesting thought's, I had not looked at it with the
> thought of the plug not being there. I will try that tonight. Welcome
> back and happy new year to you and the family.
>
> another few for interest, the first one, I have been getting
> indications
> this is Namban maybe, I have no idea hat the symbols are though Barry
> Thomas says he has an almost identical tsuba catalogued in a book from
> the early 1900's he is going to dig out for me.
>
> Namban ?
> http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/tsuba/symbol-tsuba-front.jpg
> http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/tsuba/symbol-tsuba-back.jpg
>
> Akasaka. I am hoping early more so than later. Construction layers are
> visible but I have not determined how many and will look closer on the
> weekend
> http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/tsuba/akasaka-2-front.jpg
> http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/tsuba/akasaka-2-back.jpg
>
> This one came as Sôheishi Sôten Tadashige. I cannot make out the mei at
> all but can see the Tadashige clearly enough
> http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/tsuba/tadashige-front.jpg
> http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/tsuba/tadashige-back.jpg
>
> Ichiryu Tomoyoshi. Dr. Robson tells me there is an exact same tsuba in
> the book Mito katana to Tosogu no Meihin and thinks whilst the mei is a
> little different, it could be the shodai or one of the students. I am
> waiting to here if anyone has a copy of this or in fact, how much this
> book is.
> http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/tsuba/tomoyoshi.jpg
> http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/tsuba/tomoyoshi-mei.jpg
>
> thanks for the band width.
>
> Rich
>
>
>
> Richard Turner
> Nihontô Message Board
> <http://members5.boardhost.com/Nihon-To/>
> - /for the discussion and sharing of all things Nihontô/
>
>
>
>
>
> Jim Gilbert wrote:
>
> > Rich,
> > Pieces like that seem to have been used to change the shape of the
> > seppa dai to accommodate a certain shape and/or size of saya and
> > tsuka. There are tsuba where the seppa dai has been enlarged by
> > fitting pieces all of the way around. Sometimes various pieces
> > (including the more common hitsuana plugs) are inserted by a later
> > collector to restore the look of the guard to something like what he
> > believes to be its original state.
> >
> > I could imagine a piece like being inserted to repair damage if it
> > were somewhere else on the guard. It's hard to imagine how that
> > particular spot would be damaged.
> >
> > I have seen a fair number of tsuba that have a pronounced
> asymmetry to
> > the shape of the seppa dai in that location. There is metal
> "missing"
> > from the same position at the upper right. My guess is that at some
> > time and/or place a slightly asymmetrical tsuka or saya shape was in
> > style and that tsuba were either made or modified to accommodate that
> > shape. I haven't come across such a koshirae and not being a sword
> > user I can't guess as to why such a shape might be desirable.
> >
> > The insert on your guard might be an attempt to change one of these
> > tsuba to the more common symmetrical oval shape.
> >
> > Any other ideas?
> >
> > Jim
> >
> >
> >
>
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
>
>
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] back on track with a tsuba question
messages.msgSnippet: Rich - Namban tsuba. Must agree with other commenst that this does not look namban (or even Hizen) to me. Being smallish in size and with that well-rounded
messages.messageBody:
Rich -

Namban tsuba. Must agree with other commenst that this does not look namban (or even Hizen) to me. Being smallish in size and with that well-rounded edge, I wonder if this might be Satsuma work. Just a gut-feeling guess.

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: Richard Turner
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, January 05, 2005 8:53 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] back on track with a tsuba question


Thanks Jim, interesting thought's, I had not looked at it with the
thought of the plug not being there. I will try that tonight. Welcome
back and happy new year to you and the family.

another few for interest, the first one, I have been getting indications
this is Namban maybe, I have no idea hat the symbols are though Barry
Thomas says he has an almost identical tsuba catalogued in a book from
the early 1900's he is going to dig out for me.

Namban ?
http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/tsuba/symbol-tsuba-front.jpg
http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/tsuba/symbol-tsuba-back.jpg

Akasaka. I am hoping early more so than later. Construction layers are
visible but I have not determined how many and will look closer on the
weekend
http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/tsuba/akasaka-2-front.jpg
http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/tsuba/akasaka-2-back.jpg

This one came as Sôheishi Sôten Tadashige. I cannot make out the mei at
all but can see the Tadashige clearly enough
http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/tsuba/tadashige-front.jpg
http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/tsuba/tadashige-back.jpg

Ichiryu Tomoyoshi. Dr. Robson tells me there is an exact same tsuba in
the book Mito katana to Tosogu no Meihin and thinks whilst the mei is a
little different, it could be the shodai or one of the students. I am
waiting to here if anyone has a copy of this or in fact, how much this
book is.
http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/tsuba/tomoyoshi.jpg
http://members.westnet.com.au/whiz/richard/tsuba/tomoyoshi-mei.jpg

thanks for the band width.

Rich



Richard Turner
Nihontô Message Board
<http://members5.boardhost.com/Nihon-To/>
- /for the discussion and sharing of all things Nihontô/





Jim Gilbert wrote:

> Rich,
> Pieces like that seem to have been used to change the shape of the
> seppa dai to accommodate a certain shape and/or size of saya and
> tsuka. There are tsuba where the seppa dai has been enlarged by
> fitting pieces all of the way around. Sometimes various pieces
> (including the more common hitsuana plugs) are inserted by a later
> collector to restore the look of the guard to something like what he
> believes to be its original state.
>
> I could imagine a piece like being inserted to repair damage if it
> were somewhere else on the guard. It's hard to imagine how that
> particular spot would be damaged.
>
> I have seen a fair number of tsuba that have a pronounced asymmetry to
> the shape of the seppa dai in that location. There is metal "missing"
> from the same position at the upper right. My guess is that at some
> time and/or place a slightly asymmetrical tsuka or saya shape was in
> style and that tsuba were either made or modified to accommodate that
> shape. I haven't come across such a koshirae and not being a sword
> user I can't guess as to why such a shape might be desirable.
>
> The insert on your guard might be an attempt to change one of these
> tsuba to the more common symmetrical oval shape.
>
> Any other ideas?
>
> Jim
>
>
>

messages.subject: Re: back on track with a tsuba question
messages.msgSnippet: Dear Rich At the risk of climbing onto my personal hobby horse, I cannot accept the suggestion that the illustrated tsuba is Namban.  Even accepting the
messages.messageBody:
Dear Rich

At the risk of climbing onto my personal hobby horse, I cannot
accept the suggestion that the illustrated tsuba is Namban. Even
accepting the redundant definition of Namban tsuba as being 'work
exhibiting foreign influences',I am unable to reconise any foreign -
even Chinese - influences on this guard. Even were such influences
be present, it would surely qualify as Hizen rather than as Namban
work?

My impression, although I would hate to have to present a reasoned
argument for it, is rather of Miochin work. Is this an acceptable
label?

Regards, John L.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] back on track with a tsuba question
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, Pieces like that seem to have been used to change the shape of the seppa dai to accommodate a certain shape and/or size of saya and tsuka.  There are
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
Pieces like that seem to have been used to change the shape of the seppa dai to accommodate a certain shape and/or size of saya and tsuka. There are tsuba where the seppa dai has been enlarged by fitting pieces all of the way around. Sometimes various pieces (including the more common hitsuana plugs) are inserted by a later collector to restore the look of the guard to something like what he believes to be its original state.

I could imagine a piece like being inserted to repair damage if it were somewhere else on the guard. It's hard to imagine how that particular spot would be damaged.

I have seen a fair number of tsuba that have a pronounced asymmetry to the shape of the seppa dai in that location. There is metal "missing" from the same position at the upper right. My guess is that at some time and/or place a slightly asymmetrical tsuka or saya shape was in style and that tsuba were either made or modified to accommodate that shape. I haven't come across such a koshirae and not being a sword user I can't guess as to why such a shape might be desirable.

The insert on your guard might be an attempt to change one of these tsuba to the more common symmetrical oval shape.

Any other ideas?

Jim



Hi all, I have had a new arrival for Christmas. This is I believe a
Kyo-shoami guard from the early to mid 1600's, in sand iron and
depicting Feathers that are used in the Tea Ceremony. Really nice old
iron, the pics don't do it justice, I will try for better ones soon.

Question, the little plate of Shakudo on the upper right hand side of
the seppa dai in photo 1, what purpose would this serve.

Cheers

Rich

messages.msgSnippet: Surely not - is it not much more likely to be an attempt at a repair to a damaged area that is more clearly seen on the ura surface of the guard?  This was
messages.messageBody:
Surely not - is it not much more likely to be an attempt at a repair to a damaged area that is more clearly seen on the ura surface of the guard? This was possibly done when the shakudo sekigane were added to the ryo-hitsu? John L.
